definitions.definition: Indicating movement towards or location at a higher place or position.

subdefinitions.definition: Away from the surface of the Earth or other planet ; in opposite direction to the downward pull of gravity .
examples: I looked up and saw the airplane overhead.
Shoots grow up and roots grow down.

subdefinitions.definition: To or at a physically higher or more elevated position.
examples: All day we climbed up and up .
Lift the carpet up and look underneath.
He lives up in the hills.

subdefinitions.definition: To an upright or erect position.
examples: sit up ; stand up ; get up out of bed

subdefinitions.definition: To a higher level of some quantity or notional quantity, such as price , volume , pitch , happiness , etc.
examples: Gold has gone up with the uncertainty in the world markets.
Turn it up , I can barely hear it.
Listen to your voice go up at the end of a question.
Cheer up , the weekend's almost here.

definitions.definition: Indicating movement in any other direction visualised as "up".

subdefinitions.definition: To or towards what is considered the top of something, irrespective of whether this is presently physically higher.
examples: Go back up to the top of the page.
As I lay on my back, a pain shot up from my toes to my chest.

subdefinitions.definition: To the north (as north is at the top of typical maps).
examples: I live in Florida, but I'm going up to New York to visit my family this weekend.

subdefinitions.definition: Towards or at a central place, or any place that is visualised as 'up' by virtue of local features or local convention, or arbitrarily, irrespective of direction or elevation change.
examples: We travelled from Yorkshire up to London.
I'm going up to the other end of town.
He lives up by the railway station.

subdefinitions.definition: Towards the principal terminus , towards milepost zero.
To university, especially to Cambridge or Oxford .
examples: She's going up to read Classics this September.

subdefinitions.definition: Towards the source of a river, against the direction of flow.
examples: We started in London and rowed all the way up to Oxford.

definitions.definition: To or in a position of equal advance or equality; not short of, back of, less advanced than, away from, etc.; usually followed by to or with .
examples: I was up to my chin in water.
A stranger came up and asked me for directions.
I'm going to be walking quickly, but try to keep up with me.

definitions.definition: Used as an aspect marker to indicate a completed action or state; thoroughly , completely .
examples: I will mix up the puzzle pieces.
Tear up the contract.
He really messed up .
Please type up our monthly report.
Drink up . The pub is closing.
Can you sum up your research?
The meteor burned up in the atmosphere.
I need to sew up the hole in this shirt.
I picked up some milk on the way home.
The committee will take up your request.
She had to give up her driver's license after the accident.
Instead of apologising, he offered up excuse after excuse.

definitions.definition: Aside or away, so as no longer to be present or in use.

examples: The bowler pitched the ball up .
A Cosmopolitan is typically served up .

main_definition: Indicating movement towards or location at a higher place or position.
secondary_definitions: Indicating movement in any other direction visualised as "up".
To or in a position of equal advance or equality; not short of, back of, less advanced than, away from, etc.; usually followed by to or with .
( intensifier ) Used as an aspect marker to indicate a completed action or state; thoroughly , completely .
Aside or away, so as no longer to be present or in use.
( cricket ) Relatively close to the batsman .
